column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=.PHI..sub..DELTA. =2m.pi..DELTA./.LAMBDA.
#Text=where m denotes the order of diffraction, and .LAMBDA. represents the grating period.
#Text=It is surprising that the phase modulation .PHI..sub..DELTA. is dependent on neither the optical wavelength nor the grating depth.

#Text=In addition, since the phase modulation is only dependent on the lateral displacement .DELTA., it is therefore possible to introduce a multilevel or even continuous level phase modulation using only two-level (or binary) surface relief structure.
#Text=FIG. 2b illustrates an optical waveguide device 300 comprising an optical waveguide 310 grown on an optical substrate 320.
#Text=A periodic grating structure 330, which is fabricated on the surface of or into the optical waveguide 310, couples the guided optical wave 340 with an external optical wave 350.

#Text=For a uniform grating coupler 330, the waveguide grating coupler theory reveals that the near field of the external optical wave 350 has a planar wavefront with an amplitude exponentially decaying along the guided wave 340 propagation direction.
#Text=This indicates that such a uniform grating coupler does not have beam shaping (e.g. focusing and splitting) capability.

#Text=Although a focusing grating coupler can be used to radiate a guided optical wave out of an optical waveguide and simultaneously to focus the radiated wave into a single focusing spot, it does not have the beam splitting function, i.e. it cannot produce more than one focusing sports.

#Text=In order to obtain these multiple functions, i.e. beam radiating, focusing and splitting, it is therefore essential to establish a mechanism which could be used to introduce phase modulation to a radiated optical wave.
#Text=This problem has not been solved so far.
#Text=In order to tackle this problem, we have therefore proposed a novel method which is illustrated in FIG. 2b.

#Text=In FIG. 2b., the grating coupler 330 is splitted into two sections 331 and 332, of which one section 331 is relatively displaced with the other section 332 by a distance .DELTA. in the direction perpendicular to the grating grooves 360.
#Text=It is expected that both sections 331 and 332 will act independently as a grating coupler.
#Text=However, we have unexpectedly discovered that the radiated optical waves (not shown), respectively radiated by 331 and 332, have a phase difference .PHI..sub..DELTA. between them described as
#Text=.PHI..sub..DELTA. =2m.pi..DELTA./.LAMBDA.
#Text=where m denotes the order of diffraction, and .LAMBDA. represents the grating period.
#Text=It is surprising that the phase modulation .PHI..sub..DELTA. is dependent on neither the optical wavelength nor the grating depth.

#Text=In addition, since the phase modulation is only dependent on the lateral displacement .DELTA., it is therefore possible to introduce a multilevel or even continuous level phase modulation using only two-level (or binary) surface relief structure.
